Astrofisica, E-38206 La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain), AP(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9QH, UK), AQ(Institut d'Astrophysique de Paris, UMR 7095 CNRS, Universit\u00e9 Pierre et Marie Curie, 75014, Paris, France), AR(Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, E-38205 La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain ; Universidad de La Laguna, Dpto. Astrofisica, E-38206 La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain), AS(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of British Columbia, 2329 West Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada), AT(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of the Western Cape, Robert Sobukwe Road, 7535 Bellville, Cape Town, South Africa ; INAF - Istituto di Radioastronomia, via Gobetti 101, 40129 Bologna, Italy), AU(Department of Astronomy and Department of Physics, University of Illinois, 1002 West Green Street, Urbana, IL 61801, USA), AV(Department of Physics, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, USA), AW(SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research, Landleven 12, 9747 AD, Groningen, The Netherlands), AX(Dark Cosmology Centre, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark ; Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Department of Physics, Durham University, South Road, Durham, DH1 3LE, UK)"], "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "823", "publication_year": "2016/05/1", "start_page": "17", "keywords": ["galaxies: high-redshift", "galaxies: starburst", "gravitational lensing: strong", "sub-millimeter: galaxies", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016ApJ...823...17N", "abstract": "We present a list of candidate gravitationally lensed dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) from the HerMES Large Mode Survey and the Herschel Stripe 82 Survey. Together, these partially overlapping surveys cover 372 deg<SUP>2</SUP> on the sky. After removing local spiral galaxies and known radio-loud blazars, our candidate list of lensed DSFGs is composed of 77 sources with 500 \u03bcm flux densities (S <SUB>500</SUB>) greater than 100 mJy. Such sources are dusty starburst galaxies similar to the first bright sub-millimeter galaxies (SMGs) discovered with SCUBA. We expect a large fraction of this list to be strongly lensed, with a small fraction made up of bright SMG-SMG mergers that appear as hyper-luminous infrared galaxies ({L}<SUB>{IR</SUB>}\\gt {10}<SUP>13</SUP> {L}<SUB>\u2609 </SUB>). Thirteen of the 77 candidates have spectroscopic redshifts from CO spectroscopy with ground-based interferometers, putting them at z\\gt 1 and well above the redshift of the foreground lensing galaxies. The surface density of our sample is 0.21 \u00b1 0.03 deg<SUP>-2</SUP>. We present follow-up imaging of a few of the candidates to confirm their lensing nature. The sample presented here is an ideal tool for higher-resolution imaging and spectroscopic observations to understand the detailed properties of starburst phenomena in distant galaxies. <P />Herschel is an ESA space observatory with science instruments provided by European-led Principal Investigator consortia and with important participation from NASA.", "doi": "10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17", <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">CANDIDATE GRAVITATIONALLY LENSED DUSTY STAR-FORMING GALAXIES IN THE <I>HERSCHEL</I> WIDE AREA SURVEYS<SUP>*</SUP>  </h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">H. Nayyeri</span><sup>1</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">M. Keele</span><sup>1</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">A.            Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2016 March 14</span><br />\n            \n                    Published <span itemprop=\"datePublished\">2016 May 17</span><br />\n                </p>\n    </div>\n<!-- End Dates -->\n\n<!-- Start Crossmark -->\n\t\t\t\t<p class=\"wd-jnl-art-crossmark\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://crossmark.crossref.org/dialog/?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17&domain=pdf\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/CROSSMARK_Color_horizontal.svg\" width=\"130\" alt=\"Check for updates using Crossmark\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t\t\t</p>\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End Crossmark -->\n\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Peer Review Metrics -->\n<!-- End Peer Review Metrics -->\n\n<!--  Start Citation -->\n                    <!--  End Citation -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-doi\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<abbr title=\"digital object identifier\">DOI</abbr>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p><a itemprop=\"sameAs\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17\">https://doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- End Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- Start Annotations -->\n <!-- End Annotations --><div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-aas-keywords\">\n\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F18&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+high-redshift\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F39&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+starburst\">galaxies: starburst</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>;  sub-millimeter: galaxies </p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS feed -->\n                    <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper jnl-notifications-wrapper--rss\">\n                        <a class=\"wd-jnl-rss\" href=\"/journal/rss/0004-637X\"><span\n                                class=\"icon-feed icon-feed--jhp\"></span>Journal RSS</a>\n                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- End Journal RSS feed -->\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Email Alert -->\n    <!-- Start Email Alert -->\n        <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n            <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert loginRequired\"\n               href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Farticle%2F10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F823%2F1%2F17\"\n               id=\"corridors-create-manage\" title=\"Create or edit your corridor alerts\">\n                <span class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create or edit your corridor alerts\n            </a>\n\n<!-- Start TOC Subjects Popup -->\n<span class=\"overlay-set\" id=\"corridor-alerts-overlay\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel two-columns\">\n        <div id=\"innerContainer\">\n            <a class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" title=\"Close\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\">\n                <span class=\"icon-close\"></span>\n            </a>\n            <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">\n                Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.\n            </p>\n            <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F823%2F1%2F17\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/823/1/17</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>We present a list of candidate gravitationally lensed dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) from the HerMES Large Mode Survey and the <I>Herschel</I> Stripe 82 Survey. Together, these partially overlapping surveys cover 372 deg<SUP>2</SUP> on the sky. After removing local spiral galaxies and known radio-loud blazars, our candidate list of lensed DSFGs is composed of 77 sources with 500 <I>\u03bc</I>m flux densities (<I>S</I> <SUB>500</SUB>) greater than 100 mJy. Such sources are dusty starburst galaxies similar to the first bright sub-millimeter galaxies (SMGs) discovered with SCUBA. We expect a large fraction of this list to be strongly lensed, with a small fraction made up of bright SMG\u2013SMG mergers that appear as hyper-luminous infrared galaxies (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}\\gt {10}^{13}\\;{L}_{\\odot }$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/apj523326ieqn1.gif\"></IMG>). Thirteen of the 77 candidates have spectroscopic redshifts from CO spectroscopy with ground-based interferometers, putting them at <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/apj523326ieqn2.gif\"></IMG> and well above the redshift of the foreground lensing galaxies. The surface density of our sample is 0.21 \u00b1 0.03 deg<SUP>\u22122</SUP>. We present follow-up imaging of a few of the candidates to confirm their lensing nature. The sample presented here is an ideal tool for higher-resolution imaging and spectroscopic observations to understand the detailed properties of starburst phenomena in distant galaxies.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/823/1/17&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/823/1/17&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016ApJ...823...17N\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2016ApJ...823...17N&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2016ApJ...823...17N\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s1\" name=\"apj523326s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) are among the most intensely star-forming systems in the universe (see review by Casey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib17\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib17\">2014</a>). Optical studies of these galaxies are challenging, due to high dust obscuration that absorbs the rest-frame ultraviolet (UV) light emitted by young and hot stars. Instead, these sources are bright at longer wavelengths due to the emission from heated dust (Draine &amp; Li <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib28\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib28\">2001</a>; Siebenmorgen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib93\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib93\">2014</a>). The far-infrared luminous DSFGs are bright in sub-millimeter wavelengths and are similar to the first bright sub-millimeter galaxies (SMGs) discovered with SCUBA (Smail et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib97\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib97\">1997</a>; Barger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib6\">1998</a>; Blain et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib9\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib9\">1999</a>; Dunne et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib29\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib29\">2000</a>; Chapman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib19\">2005</a>; Tacconi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib105\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib105\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib106\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib106\">2008</a>; Magnelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib67\">2012</a>; Hayward et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib48\">2013</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib103\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib103\">2014</a>; Wiklind et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib114\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib114\">2014</a>; Ikarashi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib52\">2015</a>) with the brightest sources in the far-infrared bands (with infrared luminosities of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn3.gif\" alt=\"${10}^{12}\\;{L}_{\\odot }\\lt {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}\\lt {10}^{13}\\;{L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{10}^{12}\\;{L}_{\\odot }\\lt {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}\\lt {10}^{13}\\;{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>) classified as ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs; Sanders et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib89\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib89\">1988</a>; Sanders &amp; Mirabel <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib88\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib88\">1996</a>; Lutz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib65\">1999</a>; Alonso-Herrero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib3\">2006</a>; Clements et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib20\">2010</a>; Kilerci Eser et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib58\">2014</a>; Magdis et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib66\">2014</a>). Resolved imaging of DSFGs at high redshifts is challenging given the intrinsic faintness of such systems (with intrinsic flux densities of typically 10 mJy at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m, from models or direct observations such as Ivison et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib53\">2010</a>; B\u00e9thermin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib7\">2012a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib8\">2012b</a>, or from lensing magnification-corrected 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m studies such as Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) and/or the large point-spread functions of single-dish, diffraction-limited observations at sub-millimeter wavelengths. Although the latter is no longer a limitation because of multi-dish observations, such as with ALMA using long baselines (Karim et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib56\">2013</a>; Wang et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib111\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib111\">2013</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>; Simpson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib96\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib96\">2015b</a>; ALMA Partnership et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib1\">2015a</a>), the field of view remains limited to a few arcseconds (Karim et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib56\">2013</a>). As a result, current studies of high-redshift DSFGs are generally limited to a small number of targets (Capak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib14\">2008</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib80\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib80\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib81\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib81\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>; Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>) and the most highly magnified star-forming systems (such as the Cosmic Eyelash; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib102\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib102\">2010b</a>) or extreme starbursts (Coppin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib23\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib23\">2009</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib81\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib81\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>; De Breuck et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib25\">2014</a>; Gilli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib41\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib41\">2014</a>).</p><p>Gravitational lensing provides a valuable tool to study galaxies that would otherwise be too distant or faint for current observational facilities (e.g., Treu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib108\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib108\">2010</a>; Treu &amp; Ellis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib108\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib108\">2014</a>). This is due to the fact that lensing enhances the apparent angular size and magnifies the source flux density (Atek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib5\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib5\">2014</a>; Richard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib78\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib78\">2014</a>), enabling studies of sources with intrinsic brightness below the nominal source detection limits of current facilities (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). By searching blank-field sub-millimeter surveys for bright sources, we can select galaxies that are more likely to be magnified by lensing (Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib103\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib103\">2014</a>; Simpson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib95\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib95\">2015a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib96\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib96\">2015b</a>). With the advent of large-area far-infrared and sub-millimeter surveys, it is now possible to search for bright sources as candidate gravitationally lensed systems with selection based only on the sub-millimeter flux density (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib70\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib70\">2007</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>).</p><p>The <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Pilbratt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib77\">2010</a>) provided us with a unique opportunity to study DSFGs at high redshift. This is possible through both large-area sky surveys, such as the <em>Herschel</em> Astrophysical Terahertz Large-Area Survey (H-ATLAS; Eales et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib33\">2010</a>), and deeper observations over smaller areas, such as those of the <em>Herschel</em> Multi-tiered Extragalactic Survey (HerMES; Oliver et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>). Large-area searches for gravitationally lensed systems have been very successful over the past few years at identifying high-redshift DSFGs. In particular, <em>Herschel</em> has been successful at identifying rare lensing systems, with some detailed studies already provided in the literature (Ivison et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib53\">2010</a>; Cox et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib24\">2011</a>; Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib35\">2012</a>; Messias et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib68\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib68\">2014</a>). Follow-up observations of these candidates with ground-based facilities (such as ALMA; Messias et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib68\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib68\">2014</a>; Schaerer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib91\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib91\">2015</a>) and the <em>Hubble</em> Space Telescope in the near-infrared have revealed the nature of the ISM in these systems with spatial resolutions at the level of 100 pc scales (Karim et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib56\">2013</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib103\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib103\">2014</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib104\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib104\">2015</a>). This allows us to study the gas regulation and kinematics inside distant galaxies, which sheds light on the star-formation mechanism and efficiency in the most gas-rich systems during the peak epoch of star formation in the universe (Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>). An interesting example is SDP.81, which was initially identified with <em>Herschel</em> during the Science Demonstration Phase (SDP; Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>) as a lensed DSFG (Frayer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib34\">2011</a>; Hopwood et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib51\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib51\">2011</a>; Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib31\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib31\">2014</a>; Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib72\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib72\">2014</a>). SDP.81 was later used for Science Verification observations of ALMA long baselines (ALMA Partnership et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib2\">2015b</a>). Those data, collected over more than 30 hr, have resulted in a robust lens model and have enabled ISM studies by revealing clumpy structures and giant molecular clouds within the lensed galaxy down to 80 pc scales (Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib32\">2015</a>; Hatsukade et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib47\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib47\">2015</a>; Rybak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib85\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib85\">2015a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib86\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib86\">2015b</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib104\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib104\">2015</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib115\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib115\">2015</a>; Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib50\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib50\">2016</a>).</p><p>The aim of this work is to expand the currently known samples of bright, lensed galaxies from <em>Herschel</em>. The first study of this kind used the SDP map of H-ATLAS spanning 14 deg<sup>2</sup> in Negrello et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>), identifying five candidate lenses that were confirmed to be lensed based on follow-up data. The second systematic search for lensing systems in <em>Herschel</em> imaging data appeared in Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>), who selected 13 candidate lensed systems over 95 deg<sup>2</sup> of HerMES, which was composed of many smaller fields with individual sizes at the level of 2\u201310 deg<sup>2</sup>. Among those 13 systems, 11 are now confirmed as strong lens systems; the 2 remaining systems are luminous SMG\u2013SMG mergers (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>).</p><p>Here, we extend these two earlier studies using <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE (Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver; Griffin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib45\">2010</a>) observations at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m to select potentially gravitationally lensed galaxies in the HerMES Large Mode Survey (HeLMS) and <em>Herschel</em> Stripe 82 Survey (HerS; Viero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>) fields. <em>Herschel</em> HeLMS is composed of wide, SPIRE-only observations covering an area of 301 deg<sup>2</sup> in the SDSS Stripe 82 region with ancillary data from several facilities (Oliver et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>, C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation). The SPIRE observations reach a 5<em>\u03c3</em> limiting depth of 48 mJy at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. The equatorial SDSS Stripe 82 HerS observations cover an area of 81 deg<sup>2</sup> with an average depth of 14.8 mJy beam<sup>\u22121</sup> (Viero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>, C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation). Combined with the ancillary data available in these equatorial fields, in particular the deep SDSS observations from Stripe 82, this enables us to identify and study these lensed galaxies.</p><p>The catalog presented here has <em>Herschel</em> photometry measured in the three SPIRE bands. Follow-up observations with Keck/NIRC2 using Laser-guided adaptive optics (LGSAO) and with the seeing-limited William Herschel Telescope (WHT) LIRIS near-IR imaging instrument reveal the lensing nature of several of these systems. We also present follow-up observations of some of these sources with millimeter-wave interferometric spectroscopy of CO emission lines to determine the redshift of background lensed galaxies. In particular, we present redshifts measured for targeted background lensed DSFGs with CO (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn4.gif\" alt=\"$1\\to 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\to 0</script></span></span>) observations by the Green Bank Telescope (GBT)/Zpectrometer (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation) and with multiple CO lines from the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter-wave Astronomy (CARMA) and Plateau de Bure Interferometer (PdBI; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation) showing that the confirmed lensed galaxies are at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn5.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span> with a target being at redshift as high as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 5</script></span></span>. The SDSS-detected foreground lensing galaxies have mean photometric redshifts peaking at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0.4</script></span></span> with spectroscopic observations for some of the targets confirming <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 1</script></span></span>.</p><p>The paper is organized as follows. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s2\">2</a>, we discuss the lensed galaxy selection along with photometry measurements. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s3\">3</a> describes some of the follow-up programs and existing results. We discuss our candidate lens sample, their statistical properties, and some example lensed sources in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s4\">4</a>. We conclude with a summary in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s5\">5</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume a standard cosmology with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${H}_{0}=70\\ \\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{H}_{0}=70\\ \\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.3</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7</script></span></span>.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s2\" name=\"apj523326s2\">2.\u00a0IDENTIFICATION OF CANDIDATE SOURCES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Our candidate lensed DSFGs are selected from HeLMS and HerS blank-field data.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj523326fn2\">25</a></sup>\n HeLMS and HerS cover 301.3 and 80.5 deg<sup>2</sup>, respectively, overlapping in a ~10 deg<sup>2</sup> region. HeLMS is the widest area tier of HerMES (Oliver et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>), the SPIRE Team's Guaranteed Time Observations (GTO) with <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Pilbratt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib77\">2010</a>). We use the maximum likelihood map maker <span class=\"small-caps\">sanepic</span> (Signal and Noise Estimation Procedure Including Correlations; Patanchon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib75\">2008</a>) to create our maps. We refer the reader to Asboth et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>) and C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation) for details related to HeLMS, data processing, and map making. Similar details related to HerS are available in Viero et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>). The maps we produced are comparable in quality to publicly available maps from HerS, while for the HeLMS data we compare our maps to the results from the SMAP/SHIM iterative map maker (Levenson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib61\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib61\">2010</a>). The differences, if any, are at large angular scales related to the diffuse background. For point sources and point-source flux estimation, the different maps showed a comparable performance within the uncertainties related to instrumental and confusion noise. The nominal pixel sizes at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m are 6, 8.3, and 12 arcsec, respectively, matching one-third of the FWHM of the beam in each band (18, 25, and 36 arcsec, respectively). We used and compared multiple catalogs as part of this study. The first set of catalogs make use of <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> (Savage &amp; Oliver <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib90\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib90\">2007</a>; Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib98\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib98\">2012</a>), available from the <em>Herschel</em> Interactive Processing Environment (HIPE; Ott <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib74\">2010</a>), based on sources detected at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m each. The second set is discussed in C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation) using <span class=\"small-caps\">starfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">desphot</span>. The latter makes use of 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detections to cross-identify and de-blend at 350 and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux densities, which reduces contamination from blended sources (XID catalogs).</p><p>Here, we primarily focus on bright sources with flux densities above 100 mJy at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. While our initial selection is performed with catalogs based on each of the wavelengths, using <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> catalogs, the final selection involves removal of sources that are flagged as potentially blended systems using the XID catalogs of C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation). Unlike C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation), who required a 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detection, we are able to search for and catalog lensed candidates that are also \"red\" with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{{\\rm{250}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{350}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{500}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{{\\rm{250}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{350}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{500}}}</script></span></span> (Asboth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). Bright, 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m sources are dominated by gravitationally lensed galaxies, local spiral galaxies, and blazars (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). Both local spirals and blazars can be excluded via cross-matching with shallow full-sky surveys at optical and radio wavelengths, respectively. This method has recently been exploited in other <em>Herschel</em> fields to select high-redshift gravitationally lensed galaxies (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib72\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib72\">2014</a>; Conley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib21\">2011</a>; Gonz\u00e1lez-Nuevo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib43\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). After correction for contamination, this technique has been shown to be very successful at generating a robust catalog of gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>).</p><p>We remove local galaxies from our catalogs by searching the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED) and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III Data Release 12 at the 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m positions of our sources. Local galaxies are then recognized by visual inspection of the SDSS cutouts and identified by name in NED. There are 273 such sources in our fields: 231 from HeLMS and 44 from HerS (2 lie in the overlapping region). These sources are all within 200 Mpc. As these local galaxies are rare (0.74 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>) and occupy only a small portion of the fields, positional alignment between background DSFGs and these local galaxies should not be significant. Furthermore, the typical distance ratio between the foreground and background populations is such that, in the case of chance alignments, the foreground galaxy will not act as a strong gravitational lens. Hence, we do not expect to lose bona fide strongly lensed galaxies by removing the local spirals. The relative colors of the local galaxies and lens candidates also typically occupy different regions of the color space. We also remove radio-loud blazars in a similar fashion, searching NED for all sources within 12 arcsec of the position of the peak 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux. Sources identified as radio-loud quasars in previous surveys are then removed from our target list. We found nine blazars using this method. Note that our search was simply limited to known radio-loud blazars and we did not search for new blazar candidates. Given the existence of archival radio surveys down to sufficient depth, we do not consider contamination from unknown blazars to be a significant issue in the candidate lensed sample.</p><p>After removal of the aforementioned contaminants, we examine our target lists from HeLMS and HerS for sources present in both catalogs from the 15 deg<sup>2</sup> region covered by both surveys. These duplicate sources are found by matching every source in the HeLMS catalog to the source with the nearest position in HerS, as measured by peak <em>S</em><sub>250</sub> flux. The SPIRE observations at 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m have better angular resolution (FWHM = 18'') compared to the redder bands, which makes it more suitable for the cross-matching. Duplicate sources have a nominal separation that is small compared to the separation between sources that are merely nearby in a two-dimensional sky projection, between 1.3 and 7.2 arcsec in all cases. In comparison, the two closest distinct sources in the combined catalog are separated by 45 arcsec. The flux densities at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m, and the colors of the sources, can also be compared to provide confirmation that sources from the two catalogs are indeed duplicates. Through this process, we found eight lens candidates that are present in both HeLMS and HerS, as well as the two previously mentioned local galaxies. In these cases, we remove the source from the HeLMS catalog and use the position and flux data from the deeper HerS data in all of our catalogs and analysis.</p><p>Next, we generate cutouts at the positions of the peak <em>S</em><sub>250</sub> flux from the HeLMS and HerS maps at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m for all of the sources with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy, which together define our primary lens candidate catalog. These cutouts are presented in the <xref summary=\"re presented in the Appendix. From this list, we\">Appendix</xref>. From this list, we removed any remaining spatially extended sources and those sources that are blended in <em>S</em><sub>500</sub> compared to the 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m imaging. Extended sources that are bright at sub-millimeter wavelengths, but which are not local galaxies, are primarily galactic cirrus clouds and are not of interest for this catalog (Low et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib63\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib63\">1984</a>; Silva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib94\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib94\">1998</a>; Rowan-Robinson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib84\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib84\">2014</a>). We identify point sources that are separate by at least two beam sizes (separations <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 40^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 40^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span>) in the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m band. This should include any cluster lensed galaxies such as HLSW-01 with a separation of 9'', identified in HerMES (Conley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib21\">2011</a>; Gavazzi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib37\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib37\">2011</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib79\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib79\">2011</a>; Scott et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib92\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib92\">2011</a>). We further cross-matched our catalog of HeLMS/HerS sources with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy against the photometrically selected galaxy cluster catalog of Durret et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib30\">2015</a>) in Stripe 82. We found no cluster lensing systems within our 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m bright sources.</p><p>As mentioned above, one of the caveats of the <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> catalogs is the difficulty in de-blending sources. In order to check the robustness of our bright 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m lensed DSFG candidates, we cross-checked our <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> identified sources with the <span class=\"small-caps\">starfinder</span>+250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detected XID catalog (Viero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>, C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation), which used 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m positions to de-blend the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux densities. The only disadvantage of this catalog is that it relies on 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detections, and thus does not contain 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m peakers with faint 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m emission. Using this combination of two catalogs, we identified close to 30 sources which appear to be clear blends in 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m, but show up as a single source at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. Since they are likely multiple faint sources, rather than a single bright object, we do not consider such cases to be reliable candidates for gravitationally lensed sources. This approach, however, also results in the potential removal of rare lensed galaxies with image separations at the level of 30 arcsec or more. Such lensing will involve most massive galaxy clusters in the foreground and are best searched for by combining SPIRE catalogs and known galaxy cluster positions. Given that our goal is to obtain a reliable list with high efficiency for lensing, and not necessarily a complete list of all lensed galaxies, we consider our approach to be adequate to increase the reliability that a higher fraction of the sources in our candidate list are gravitationally lensed DSFGs.</p><p>After removing blended sources and sources that are extended\u2014and thus likely to be contaminants from Galactic cirrus clumps (see C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation)\u2014we are left with a total of 77 lensed candidate galaxies with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy in our primary candidate list. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy candidates have a surface density of 0.21 \u00b1 0.03 deg<sup>\u22122</sup> over the HeLMS and HerS fields. Using a sample of lensed DSFGs in the HerMES field, Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) measured a space density of 0.14 deg<sup>\u22122</sup> for systems with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy for a candidate lensed sample composed of 13 systems. Among the 13, 2 have since been identified as SMG\u2013SMG mergers, although there is evidence in both cases for moderate lensing with magnification factors between 1.3 and 1.8 (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>). With those two systems removed, the actual surface density of lensed galaxies with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy in HerMES is around 0.11 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>. This is substantially smaller than the surface density of our candidate list at 0.21 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>. We expect that ~15% of our sample are also composed of SMG\u2013SMG mergers, which would be similar to the sources studied in Fu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>) and Ivison et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib54\">2013</a>). The real difference is likely due to cosmic variance. The study by Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) involves multiple smaller legacy fields that were used in HerMES to form 95 deg<sup>2</sup>. These extragalactic legacy fields, such as XMM-LSS or Bo\u00f6tes, are carefully selected to be devoid of known low-<em>z</em> (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$z=0.1\\mbox{--}0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z=0.1\\mbox{--}0.3</script></span></span>) massive galaxy clusters or galaxy over-densities that could potentially lens background DSFGs. Thus, these fields may, on average, provide a lower optical depth to lensing than a blank-sky field. This is also visible in comparison to another result. The first lens selection with <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE in H-ATLAS resulted in five confirmed lensed galaxies with a sky surface density of 0.35 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>. While this area was 14 deg<sup>2</sup>, it shows large field-to-field variation in the number of lensed sources. This cosmic variance is a combination of the spatial distribution of massive foreground galaxies or galaxy over-densities and the clustering of background DSFGs. With proper statistics on the lensed fraction from HeLMS and HerS, as well as the lensed sample over 650 deg<sup>2</sup> of H-ATLAS which has yet to fully appear in the literature, we expect that it will be possible to observationally constrain the lensing optical depth variations of <em>Herschel</em>-selected DSFGs. A theoretical calculation of the expected cosmic variance will also be useful to address which parameters related to either the background DSFG population or foreground lenses can be constrained with such statistics.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s3\" name=\"apj523326s3\">3.\u00a0FOLLOW-UP OBSERVATIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj523326s3-1\" name=\"apj523326s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Redshifts</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The redshifts of gas-rich DSFGs can be determined using CO rotational emission lines in radio observations. This method has been used extensively to measure the redshifts of distant DSFGs (Greve et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib44\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib44\">2005</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib101\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib101\">2010a</a>; Harris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>; Lupu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib64\">2012</a>; George et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib40\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib40\">2013</a>; Wei\u00df et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib113\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib113\">2013</a>; Decarli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib26\">2014</a>; Canameras et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib13\">2015</a>; Zavala et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib117\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib117\">2015</a>). CO molecular line observations are also used to study the physical propertied of SMGs and DSFGs (Solomon &amp; Vanden Bout <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib99\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib99\">2005</a>; Tacconi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib105\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib105\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib106\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib106\">2008</a>; Carilli &amp; Walter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib15\">2013</a>). In particular, CO brightness and spatial distribution could be utilized to determine the total molecular gas content and extent, which is responsible for star formation, in these gas-rich systems (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib35\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Narayanan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib69\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib69\">2012</a>). As part of existing programs to follow-up <em>Herschel</em>-selected bright lensed galaxies, we obtained radio/millimeter CO redshift measurements of 12 sources in our HeLMS+HerS sample with the Robert C. Byrd GBT (7 sources; A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation), CARMA (12 sources; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation), and IRAM/PdBI (11 sources; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation), and one source (HELMS29) with spectroscopic observations from ALMA (Asboth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). The 12 sources with redshifts reported here come from a large sample of lensed <em>Herschel</em> sources, involving all of the wide-area <em>Herschel</em> fields. The CO sample follows no particular selection criterion apart from flexibility in scheduling with each of the facilities. The GBT observations target the CO(1 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$\\to $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\to</script></span></span> 0) transition, however, as discussed in Harris et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>), it is also possible to have a GBT CO(2 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$\\to $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\to</script></span></span> 1) transition for systems at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"$5.1\\lt z\\lt 8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">5.1\\lt z\\lt 8</script></span></span> or a line from species other than the CO, but this would be unlikely given the photometric redshift distributions and the weak nature of the other line species (Harris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>). The lensed DSFG candidates with confirmed spectroscopic redshift from CO observations have 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m fluxes exceeding 121 mJy with a median flux of 164 mJy in the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. The spectroscopic observations confirmed the brighter candidates in the far-infrared, demonstrating the increased chance of detection for brighter objects (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation, D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation).</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f1\">1</a> shows the redshift distribution of the background DSFGs measured from CO. The measured redshifts of the background sources are at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span> and peak at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2.5</script></span></span>. This result is consistent with other studies of SMG redshift distributions (Chapman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib19\">2005</a>; Harris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>). Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f1\">1</a> also shows the redshift distribution of the foreground lensing galaxies. This result is derived from public SDSS catalogs and is mostly for brighter optical counterparts (due to limited spectroscopic depth). However, our spectroscopic campaigns on the <em>Herschel</em>-selected lensing systems have successfully measured the individual galaxy spectra using large ground-based observatories such as Keck (DEIMOS and LRIS) along with observations from Gemini, MMT, and VLT (Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>). The redshift distribution of the foreground galaxies peaks at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 1</script></span></span> and is consistent with the scenario in which a background high-redshift galaxy is being gravitationally lensed by a foreground system at much lower redshift.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Redshift distribution of the 13 HeLMS and HerS candidate lensed galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts from CO observations (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation, D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation). The DSFGs are at a median redshift of 2.51, while the foreground galaxies have a median redshift of 0.44, putting the background lensed systems at much higher redshifts compared to the foreground lensing galaxies. The inset shows the redshift distribution of the local spiral galaxies that are bright in the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj523326s3-2\" name=\"apj523326s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Imaging</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As part of a \"HELMS Deep\" observing campaign, several of the lens candidates have been followed up with high-resolution imaging with Keck/NIRC2 laser-guided adaptive optics (LGSAO) and with seeing-limited imaging with the WHT LIRIS instrument in the near-infrared. These observations were designed to study the rest-frame optical properties of these lensed systems in detail, as has been done over the past few years for other DSFGs at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span> (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib35\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Calanog et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib12\">2014</a>; Timmons et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib107\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib107\">2015</a>). HELMS Deep observations of the lensed candidates were obtained with the Keck/NIRC2 AO system in the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span> band at 2.2 <em>\u03bc</em>m in 2015 August and September (PI: Cooray). The observations were performed with an average exposure time of 3600 s over two nights under cloudy conditions and poor AO correction. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f2\">2</a> shows the Keck II/NIRC2-LGSAO <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span>-band images of two of the lensed systems for which we obtained reliable data in these runs based on the new catalog presented here. The two galaxies (HERS1, discussed below and identified elsewhere as a lensing galaxy, and HERS6) both show clear lensing features in the near-infrared composed of arcs and counter images. A detailed analysis of these imaging data, in combination with other multi-wavelength interferometric images, including those from an ALMA snapshot program (PI: Eales), will be presented in future papers.
