This is due to the fact that lensing enhances the apparent angular size and magnifies the source flux density (Atek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib5\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib5\">2014</a>; Richard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib78\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib78\">2014</a>), enabling studies of sources with intrinsic brightness below the nominal source detection limits of current facilities (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). By searching blank-field sub-millimeter surveys for bright sources, we can select galaxies that are more likely to be magnified by lensing (Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib103\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib103\">2014</a>; Simpson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib95\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib95\">2015a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib96\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib96\">2015b</a>). With the advent of large-area far-infrared and sub-millimeter surveys, it is now possible to search for bright sources as candidate gravitationally lensed systems with selection based only on the sub-millimeter flux density (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib70\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib70\">2007</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>).</p><p>The <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Pilbratt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib77\">2010</a>) provided us with a unique opportunity to study DSFGs at high redshift. This is possible through both large-area sky surveys, such as the <em>Herschel</em> Astrophysical Terahertz Large-Area Survey (H-ATLAS; Eales et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib33\">2010</a>), and deeper observations over smaller areas, such as those of the <em>Herschel</em> Multi-tiered Extragalactic Survey (HerMES; Oliver et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>). Large-area searches for gravitationally lensed systems have been very successful over the past few years at identifying high-redshift DSFGs. In particular, <em>Herschel</em> has been successful at identifying rare lensing systems, with some detailed studies already provided in the literature (Ivison et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib53\">2010</a>; Cox et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib24\">2011</a>; Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib35\">2012</a>; Messias et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib68\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib68\">2014</a>). Follow-up observations of these candidates with ground-based facilities (such as ALMA; Messias et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib68\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib68\">2014</a>; Schaerer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib91\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib91\">2015</a>) and the <em>Hubble</em> Space Telescope in the near-infrared have revealed the nature of the ISM in these systems with spatial resolutions at the level of 100 pc scales (Karim et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib56\">2013</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib103\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib103\">2014</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib104\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib104\">2015</a>). This allows us to study the gas regulation and kinematics inside distant galaxies, which sheds light on the star-formation mechanism and efficiency in the most gas-rich systems during the peak epoch of star formation in the universe (Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib82\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib82\">2014</a>). An interesting example is SDP.81, which was initially identified with <em>Herschel</em> during the Science Demonstration Phase (SDP; Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>) as a lensed DSFG (Frayer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib34\">2011</a>; Hopwood et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib51\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib51\">2011</a>; Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib31\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib31\">2014</a>; Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib72\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib72\">2014</a>). SDP.81 was later used for Science Verification observations of ALMA long baselines (ALMA Partnership et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib2\">2015b</a>). Those data, collected over more than 30 hr, have resulted in a robust lens model and have enabled ISM studies by revealing clumpy structures and giant molecular clouds within the lensed galaxy down to 80 pc scales (Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib32\">2015</a>; Hatsukade et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib47\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib47\">2015</a>; Rybak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib85\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib85\">2015a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib86\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib86\">2015b</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib104\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib104\">2015</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib115\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib115\">2015</a>; Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib50\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib50\">2016</a>).</p><p>The aim of this work is to expand the currently known samples of bright, lensed galaxies from <em>Herschel</em>. The first study of this kind used the SDP map of H-ATLAS spanning 14 deg<sup>2</sup> in Negrello et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>), identifying five candidate lenses that were confirmed to be lensed based on follow-up data. The second systematic search for lensing systems in <em>Herschel</em> imaging data appeared in Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>), who selected 13 candidate lensed systems over 95 deg<sup>2</sup> of HerMES, which was composed of many smaller fields with individual sizes at the level of 2\u201310 deg<sup>2</sup>. Among those 13 systems, 11 are now confirmed as strong lens systems; the 2 remaining systems are luminous SMG\u2013SMG mergers (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>).</p><p>Here, we extend these two earlier studies using <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE (Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver; Griffin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib45\">2010</a>) observations at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m to select potentially gravitationally lensed galaxies in the HerMES Large Mode Survey (HeLMS) and <em>Herschel</em> Stripe 82 Survey (HerS; Viero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>) fields. <em>Herschel</em> HeLMS is composed of wide, SPIRE-only observations covering an area of 301 deg<sup>2</sup> in the SDSS Stripe 82 region with ancillary data from several facilities (Oliver et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>, C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation). The SPIRE observations reach a 5<em>\u03c3</em> limiting depth of 48 mJy at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. The equatorial SDSS Stripe 82 HerS observations cover an area of 81 deg<sup>2</sup> with an average depth of 14.8 mJy beam<sup>\u22121</sup> (Viero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>, C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation). Combined with the ancillary data available in these equatorial fields, in particular the deep SDSS observations from Stripe 82, this enables us to identify and study these lensed galaxies.</p><p>The catalog presented here has <em>Herschel</em> photometry measured in the three SPIRE bands. Follow-up observations with Keck/NIRC2 using Laser-guided adaptive optics (LGSAO) and with the seeing-limited William Herschel Telescope (WHT) LIRIS near-IR imaging instrument reveal the lensing nature of several of these systems. We also present follow-up observations of some of these sources with millimeter-wave interferometric spectroscopy of CO emission lines to determine the redshift of background lensed galaxies. In particular, we present redshifts measured for targeted background lensed DSFGs with CO (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn4.gif\" alt=\"$1\\to 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\to 0</script></span></span>) observations by the Green Bank Telescope (GBT)/Zpectrometer (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation) and with multiple CO lines from the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter-wave Astronomy (CARMA) and Plateau de Bure Interferometer (PdBI; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation) showing that the confirmed lensed galaxies are at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn5.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span> with a target being at redshift as high as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 5</script></span></span>. The SDSS-detected foreground lensing galaxies have mean photometric redshifts peaking at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0.4</script></span></span> with spectroscopic observations for some of the targets confirming <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 1</script></span></span>.</p><p>The paper is organized as follows. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s2\">2</a>, we discuss the lensed galaxy selection along with photometry measurements. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s3\">3</a> describes some of the follow-up programs and existing results. We discuss our candidate lens sample, their statistical properties, and some example lensed sources in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s4\">4</a>. We conclude with a summary in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s5\">5</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume a standard cosmology with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${H}_{0}=70\\ \\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{H}_{0}=70\\ \\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.3</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7</script></span></span>.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s2\" name=\"apj523326s2\">2.\u00a0IDENTIFICATION OF CANDIDATE SOURCES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Our candidate lensed DSFGs are selected from HeLMS and HerS blank-field data.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj523326fn2\">25</a></sup>\n HeLMS and HerS cover 301.3 and 80.5 deg<sup>2</sup>, respectively, overlapping in a ~10 deg<sup>2</sup> region. HeLMS is the widest area tier of HerMES (Oliver et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>), the SPIRE Team's Guaranteed Time Observations (GTO) with <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Pilbratt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib77\">2010</a>). We use the maximum likelihood map maker <span class=\"small-caps\">sanepic</span> (Signal and Noise Estimation Procedure Including Correlations; Patanchon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib75\">2008</a>) to create our maps. We refer the reader to Asboth et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>) and C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation) for details related to HeLMS, data processing, and map making. Similar details related to HerS are available in Viero et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>). The maps we produced are comparable in quality to publicly available maps from HerS, while for the HeLMS data we compare our maps to the results from the SMAP/SHIM iterative map maker (Levenson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib61\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib61\">2010</a>). The differences, if any, are at large angular scales related to the diffuse background. For point sources and point-source flux estimation, the different maps showed a comparable performance within the uncertainties related to instrumental and confusion noise. The nominal pixel sizes at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m are 6, 8.3, and 12 arcsec, respectively, matching one-third of the FWHM of the beam in each band (18, 25, and 36 arcsec, respectively). We used and compared multiple catalogs as part of this study. The first set of catalogs make use of <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> (Savage &amp; Oliver <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib90\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib90\">2007</a>; Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib98\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib98\">2012</a>), available from the <em>Herschel</em> Interactive Processing Environment (HIPE; Ott <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib74\">2010</a>), based on sources detected at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m each. The second set is discussed in C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation) using <span class=\"small-caps\">starfinder</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">desphot</span>. The latter makes use of 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detections to cross-identify and de-blend at 350 and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux densities, which reduces contamination from blended sources (XID catalogs).</p><p>Here, we primarily focus on bright sources with flux densities above 100 mJy at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. While our initial selection is performed with catalogs based on each of the wavelengths, using <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> catalogs, the final selection involves removal of sources that are flagged as potentially blended systems using the XID catalogs of C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation). Unlike C. Clarke et al. (2016, in preparation), who required a 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detection, we are able to search for and catalog lensed candidates that are also \"red\" with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{{\\rm{250}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{350}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{500}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{{\\rm{250}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{350}}}\\lt {S}_{{\\rm{500}}}</script></span></span> (Asboth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). Bright, 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m sources are dominated by gravitationally lensed galaxies, local spiral galaxies, and blazars (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). Both local spirals and blazars can be excluded via cross-matching with shallow full-sky surveys at optical and radio wavelengths, respectively. This method has recently been exploited in other <em>Herschel</em> fields to select high-redshift gravitationally lensed galaxies (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib72\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib72\">2014</a>; Conley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib21\">2011</a>; Gonz\u00e1lez-Nuevo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib43\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). After correction for contamination, this technique has been shown to be very successful at generating a robust catalog of gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>).</p><p>We remove local galaxies from our catalogs by searching the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED) and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III Data Release 12 at the 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m positions of our sources. Local galaxies are then recognized by visual inspection of the SDSS cutouts and identified by name in NED. There are 273 such sources in our fields: 231 from HeLMS and 44 from HerS (2 lie in the overlapping region). These sources are all within 200 Mpc. As these local galaxies are rare (0.74 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>) and occupy only a small portion of the fields, positional alignment between background DSFGs and these local galaxies should not be significant. Furthermore, the typical distance ratio between the foreground and background populations is such that, in the case of chance alignments, the foreground galaxy will not act as a strong gravitational lens. Hence, we do not expect to lose bona fide strongly lensed galaxies by removing the local spirals. The relative colors of the local galaxies and lens candidates also typically occupy different regions of the color space. We also remove radio-loud blazars in a similar fashion, searching NED for all sources within 12 arcsec of the position of the peak 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux. Sources identified as radio-loud quasars in previous surveys are then removed from our target list. We found nine blazars using this method. Note that our search was simply limited to known radio-loud blazars and we did not search for new blazar candidates. Given the existence of archival radio surveys down to sufficient depth, we do not consider contamination from unknown blazars to be a significant issue in the candidate lensed sample.</p><p>After removal of the aforementioned contaminants, we examine our target lists from HeLMS and HerS for sources present in both catalogs from the 15 deg<sup>2</sup> region covered by both surveys. These duplicate sources are found by matching every source in the HeLMS catalog to the source with the nearest position in HerS, as measured by peak <em>S</em><sub>250</sub> flux. The SPIRE observations at 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m have better angular resolution (FWHM = 18'') compared to the redder bands, which makes it more suitable for the cross-matching. Duplicate sources have a nominal separation that is small compared to the separation between sources that are merely nearby in a two-dimensional sky projection, between 1.3 and 7.2 arcsec in all cases. In comparison, the two closest distinct sources in the combined catalog are separated by 45 arcsec. The flux densities at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m, and the colors of the sources, can also be compared to provide confirmation that sources from the two catalogs are indeed duplicates. Through this process, we found eight lens candidates that are present in both HeLMS and HerS, as well as the two previously mentioned local galaxies. In these cases, we remove the source from the HeLMS catalog and use the position and flux data from the deeper HerS data in all of our catalogs and analysis.</p><p>Next, we generate cutouts at the positions of the peak <em>S</em><sub>250</sub> flux from the HeLMS and HerS maps at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m for all of the sources with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy, which together define our primary lens candidate catalog. These cutouts are presented in the <xref summary=\"re presented in the Appendix. From this list, we\">Appendix</xref>. From this list, we removed any remaining spatially extended sources and those sources that are blended in <em>S</em><sub>500</sub> compared to the 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m imaging. Extended sources that are bright at sub-millimeter wavelengths, but which are not local galaxies, are primarily galactic cirrus clouds and are not of interest for this catalog (Low et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib63\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib63\">1984</a>; Silva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib94\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib94\">1998</a>; Rowan-Robinson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib84\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib84\">2014</a>). We identify point sources that are separate by at least two beam sizes (separations <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 40^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 40^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span>) in the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m band. This should include any cluster lensed galaxies such as HLSW-01 with a separation of 9'', identified in HerMES (Conley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib21\">2011</a>; Gavazzi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib37\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib37\">2011</a>; Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib79\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib79\">2011</a>; Scott et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib92\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib92\">2011</a>). We further cross-matched our catalog of HeLMS/HerS sources with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy against the photometrically selected galaxy cluster catalog of Durret et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib30\">2015</a>) in Stripe 82. We found no cluster lensing systems within our 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m bright sources.</p><p>As mentioned above, one of the caveats of the <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> catalogs is the difficulty in de-blending sources. In order to check the robustness of our bright 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m lensed DSFG candidates, we cross-checked our <span class=\"small-caps\">sussextractor</span> identified sources with the <span class=\"small-caps\">starfinder</span>+250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detected XID catalog (Viero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib110\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib110\">2014</a>, C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation), which used 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m positions to de-blend the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux densities. The only disadvantage of this catalog is that it relies on 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m detections, and thus does not contain 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m peakers with faint 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m emission. Using this combination of two catalogs, we identified close to 30 sources which appear to be clear blends in 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m, but show up as a single source at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. Since they are likely multiple faint sources, rather than a single bright object, we do not consider such cases to be reliable candidates for gravitationally lensed sources. This approach, however, also results in the potential removal of rare lensed galaxies with image separations at the level of 30 arcsec or more. Such lensing will involve most massive galaxy clusters in the foreground and are best searched for by combining SPIRE catalogs and known galaxy cluster positions. Given that our goal is to obtain a reliable list with high efficiency for lensing, and not necessarily a complete list of all lensed galaxies, we consider our approach to be adequate to increase the reliability that a higher fraction of the sources in our candidate list are gravitationally lensed DSFGs.</p><p>After removing blended sources and sources that are extended\u2014and thus likely to be contaminants from Galactic cirrus clumps (see C. Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation)\u2014we are left with a total of 77 lensed candidate galaxies with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy in our primary candidate list. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy candidates have a surface density of 0.21 \u00b1 0.03 deg<sup>\u22122</sup> over the HeLMS and HerS fields. Using a sample of lensed DSFGs in the HerMES field, Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) measured a space density of 0.14 deg<sup>\u22122</sup> for systems with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy for a candidate lensed sample composed of 13 systems. Among the 13, 2 have since been identified as SMG\u2013SMG mergers, although there is evidence in both cases for moderate lensing with magnification factors between 1.3 and 1.8 (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>). With those two systems removed, the actual surface density of lensed galaxies with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy in HerMES is around 0.11 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>. This is substantially smaller than the surface density of our candidate list at 0.21 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>. We expect that ~15% of our sample are also composed of SMG\u2013SMG mergers, which would be similar to the sources studied in Fu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>) and Ivison et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib54\">2013</a>). The real difference is likely due to cosmic variance. The study by Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) involves multiple smaller legacy fields that were used in HerMES to form 95 deg<sup>2</sup>. These extragalactic legacy fields, such as XMM-LSS or Bo\u00f6tes, are carefully selected to be devoid of known low-<em>z</em> (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$z=0.1\\mbox{--}0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z=0.1\\mbox{--}0.3</script></span></span>) massive galaxy clusters or galaxy over-densities that could potentially lens background DSFGs. Thus, these fields may, on average, provide a lower optical depth to lensing than a blank-sky field. This is also visible in comparison to another result. The first lens selection with <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE in H-ATLAS resulted in five confirmed lensed galaxies with a sky surface density of 0.35 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>. While this area was 14 deg<sup>2</sup>, it shows large field-to-field variation in the number of lensed sources. This cosmic variance is a combination of the spatial distribution of massive foreground galaxies or galaxy over-densities and the clustering of background DSFGs. With proper statistics on the lensed fraction from HeLMS and HerS, as well as the lensed sample over 650 deg<sup>2</sup> of H-ATLAS which has yet to fully appear in the literature, we expect that it will be possible to observationally constrain the lensing optical depth variations of <em>Herschel</em>-selected DSFGs. A theoretical calculation of the expected cosmic variance will also be useful to address which parameters related to either the background DSFG population or foreground lenses can be constrained with such statistics.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s3\" name=\"apj523326s3\">3.\u00a0FOLLOW-UP OBSERVATIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj523326s3-1\" name=\"apj523326s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Redshifts</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The redshifts of gas-rich DSFGs can be determined using CO rotational emission lines in radio observations. This method has been used extensively to measure the redshifts of distant DSFGs (Greve et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib44\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib44\">2005</a>; Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib101\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib101\">2010a</a>; Harris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>; Lupu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib64\">2012</a>; George et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib40\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib40\">2013</a>; Wei\u00df et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib113\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib113\">2013</a>; Decarli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib26\">2014</a>; Canameras et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib13\">2015</a>; Zavala et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib117\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib117\">2015</a>). CO molecular line observations are also used to study the physical propertied of SMGs and DSFGs (Solomon &amp; Vanden Bout <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib99\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib99\">2005</a>; Tacconi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib105\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib105\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib106\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib106\">2008</a>; Carilli &amp; Walter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib15\">2013</a>). In particular, CO brightness and spatial distribution could be utilized to determine the total molecular gas content and extent, which is responsible for star formation, in these gas-rich systems (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib35\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Narayanan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib69\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib69\">2012</a>). As part of existing programs to follow-up <em>Herschel</em>-selected bright lensed galaxies, we obtained radio/millimeter CO redshift measurements of 12 sources in our HeLMS+HerS sample with the Robert C. Byrd GBT (7 sources; A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation), CARMA (12 sources; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation), and IRAM/PdBI (11 sources; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation), and one source (HELMS29) with spectroscopic observations from ALMA (Asboth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). The 12 sources with redshifts reported here come from a large sample of lensed <em>Herschel</em> sources, involving all of the wide-area <em>Herschel</em> fields. The CO sample follows no particular selection criterion apart from flexibility in scheduling with each of the facilities. The GBT observations target the CO(1 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$\\to $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\to</script></span></span> 0) transition, however, as discussed in Harris et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>), it is also possible to have a GBT CO(2 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$\\to $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\to</script></span></span> 1) transition for systems at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"$5.1\\lt z\\lt 8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">5.1\\lt z\\lt 8</script></span></span> or a line from species other than the CO, but this would be unlikely given the photometric redshift distributions and the weak nature of the other line species (Harris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>). The lensed DSFG candidates with confirmed spectroscopic redshift from CO observations have 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m fluxes exceeding 121 mJy with a median flux of 164 mJy in the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. The spectroscopic observations confirmed the brighter candidates in the far-infrared, demonstrating the increased chance of detection for brighter objects (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation, D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation).</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f1\">1</a> shows the redshift distribution of the background DSFGs measured from CO. The measured redshifts of the background sources are at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span> and peak at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2.5</script></span></span>. This result is consistent with other studies of SMG redshift distributions (Chapman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib19\">2005</a>; Harris et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib46\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>). Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f1\">1</a> also shows the redshift distribution of the foreground lensing galaxies. This result is derived from public SDSS catalogs and is mostly for brighter optical counterparts (due to limited spectroscopic depth). However, our spectroscopic campaigns on the <em>Herschel</em>-selected lensing systems have successfully measured the individual galaxy spectra using large ground-based observatories such as Keck (DEIMOS and LRIS) along with observations from Gemini, MMT, and VLT (Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>). The redshift distribution of the foreground galaxies peaks at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 1</script></span></span> and is consistent with the scenario in which a background high-redshift galaxy is being gravitationally lensed by a foreground system at much lower redshift.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Redshift distribution of the 13 HeLMS and HerS candidate lensed galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts from CO observations (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation, D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation). The DSFGs are at a median redshift of 2.51, while the foreground galaxies have a median redshift of 0.44, putting the background lensed systems at much higher redshifts compared to the foreground lensing galaxies. The inset shows the redshift distribution of the local spiral galaxies that are bright in the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj523326s3-2\" name=\"apj523326s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Imaging</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As part of a \"HELMS Deep\" observing campaign, several of the lens candidates have been followed up with high-resolution imaging with Keck/NIRC2 laser-guided adaptive optics (LGSAO) and with seeing-limited imaging with the WHT LIRIS instrument in the near-infrared. These observations were designed to study the rest-frame optical properties of these lensed systems in detail, as has been done over the past few years for other DSFGs at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span> (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib35\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Calanog et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib12\">2014</a>; Timmons et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib107\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib107\">2015</a>). HELMS Deep observations of the lensed candidates were obtained with the Keck/NIRC2 AO system in the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span> band at 2.2 <em>\u03bc</em>m in 2015 August and September (PI: Cooray). The observations were performed with an average exposure time of 3600 s over two nights under cloudy conditions and poor AO correction. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f2\">2</a> shows the Keck II/NIRC2-LGSAO <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span>-band images of two of the lensed systems for which we obtained reliable data in these runs based on the new catalog presented here. The two galaxies (HERS1, discussed below and identified elsewhere as a lensing galaxy, and HERS6) both show clear lensing features in the near-infrared composed of arcs and counter images. A detailed analysis of these imaging data, in combination with other multi-wavelength interferometric images, including those from an ALMA snapshot program (PI: Eales), will be presented in future papers. We highlight them here to motivate additional follow-up programs of the <em>Herschel</em> lens sample by the strong-lensing community.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Keck/NIRC2 AO observations of two of our lensed DSFG candidates (HERS1 and HERS6) in the <em>K</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> band at 2.2 <em>\u03bc</em>m along with William Herschel Telescope (WHT) LIRIS observations of HELMS6 in the <em>K</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> band. We clearly see lensing features in these three systems which were originally identified in the SPIRE 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m band. HERS1 is the brightest source in our catalog at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m and it has been confirmed to be gravitationally lensed in a previous study by Geach et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib38\">2015</a>) and recently with the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (Su et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The WHT/LIRIS observations of HeLMS lens candidates are part of a large program on HerMES high-redshift galaxies (PI: Prez-Fournon). The LIRIS observations were performed with a typical exposure time of 3600 s in sub-arcsecond seeing conditions. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f2\">2</a> also shows the WHT/LIRIS <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn30.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span> imaging of HELMS6 observed on 2015 October 26, with seeing of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8. In this case, the main lensing galaxy is a member of a cluster of galaxies, with SDSS photometric redshift ~0.4. Giant arcs are also present in this system. Optical long-slit spectroscopy of this field with the OSIRIS instrument of the Gran Telescopio Canarias (GTC) was obtained on 2015 November 29 in dark and clear conditions and seeing of 1.2 arcsec. The exposure time was 3000 s. We used the R1000B grism, with a spectral sampling of 2.12 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn31.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathring{\\rm A} \\;{\\mathrm{pixel}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathring{\\rm A} \\;{\\mathrm{pixel}}^{-1}</script></span></span> and a slit width of 1.2 arcsec. The slit included several of the galaxies in the cluster to the south of the main lensing galaxy. This position was chosen to include one of the lensed arc features. From these observations, we could measure the spectroscopic redshifts of three galaxies in the cluster, of 0.3950, 0.3956, and 0.3968, close to the SDSS photometric redshift. More details and analysis will be presented in R. Marques-Chaves et al. (2016, in preparation).</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s4\" name=\"apj523326s4\">4.\u00a0DISCUSSION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj523326s4-1\" name=\"apj523326s4-1\">4.1.\u00a0Far-infrared Colors</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f3\">3</a> shows 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m color-flux density plots for all of the sources detected in the HeLMS and HerS catalogs. Sources of interest, with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn32.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy, are highlighted in red, blue, and green, for our lens candidate galaxies, local galaxies, and blazars, respectively. As mentioned in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj523326s2\">2</a>, all of the flux measurements are taken from the HeLMS and HerS catalogs referenced above.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0<em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE color vs. flux density plots for all of the sources in the HeLMS and HerS catalogs. Lens candidates, local galaxies, and blazars with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn33.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\;\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\;\\gt</script></span></span> 100 mJy are shown in color while all of the sources are shown in grayscale. Median error bars for all four populations are given at the top of the figures. The DSFGs in our gravitationally lensed candidate catalog are redder than the local galaxies, which is consistent with a greater redshift. The apparent offset of the lens candidates from the grayscale general population is due to our flux cut at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}=100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}=100</script></span></span> mJy and vanishes in the color\u2013color plot (Figure <a href=\"#apj523326f4\">4</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Our primary catalog of lensed DSFG candidate galaxies has median <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{350}/{S}_{500}=1.29\\pm 0.10,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=0.90\\pm 0.06$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{350}/{S}_{500}=1.29\\pm 0.10,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=0.90\\pm 0.06</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}/{S}_{500}=1.16\\pm 0.09$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}/{S}_{500}=1.16\\pm 0.09</script></span></span> with the errors being the standard deviation of the distribution. In comparison, the general population of all sources has median <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{350}/{S}_{500}\\;=\\;1.54\\pm 0.63,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=1.34\\pm 0.33$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{350}/{S}_{500}\\;=\\;1.54\\pm 0.63,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=1.34\\pm 0.33</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn38.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}/{S}_{500}\\;=\\;2.06\\pm 0.80$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}/{S}_{500}\\;=\\;2.06\\pm 0.80</script></span></span>. These have comparable colors, as expected, since the lensed candidates are drawn from the parent population of <em>Herschel</em>-detected sources. The local galaxies have bluer colors than either the general population or our candidate lensed DSFGs, with median <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn39.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{350}/{S}_{500}=2.29\\;\\pm \\;0.13,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=2.07\\pm 0.08$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{350}/{S}_{500}=2.29\\;\\pm \\;0.13,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=2.07\\pm 0.08</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn40.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}/{S}_{500}=4.74\\pm 0.27$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}/{S}_{500}=4.74\\pm 0.27</script></span></span>. As this population is exclusively composed of galaxies at very low redshift, the relatively blue color is expected. The blazars have median <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn41.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{350}/{S}_{500}=0.68\\pm 0.08,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=0.93\\;\\pm \\;0.08$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{350}/{S}_{500}=0.68\\pm 0.08,{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}=0.93\\;\\pm \\;0.08</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn42.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}/{S}_{500}=0.63\\pm 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}/{S}_{500}=0.63\\pm 0.05</script></span></span>.</p><p>Our highlighted lens candidates, local galaxies, and blazars are offset from each other in the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn43.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}/{S}_{350}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}/{S}_{350}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn44.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250},{S}_{250}/{S}_{500}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250},{S}_{250}/{S}_{500}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn45.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{350}/{S}_{500}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{350}/{S}_{500}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn47.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}</script></span></span> color-flux space due to our selection criteria. Since we limited our search to sources that are bright in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn48.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}</script></span></span>, which are correspondingly bright in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn49.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{250}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{250}</script></span></span>, the highlighted sources all appear shifted to the right in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f3\">3</a>. As we see in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f4\">4</a>, this effect is not present in the color\u2013color space where the distribution of candidate galaxies follows the general population.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Color\u2013color plot for all sources in the HeLMS and HerS catalogs. Sources with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn50.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy are highlighted when they belong to our lensing candidate, local galaxy, or blazar catalogs. The background grayscale shows the distribution of all sources in HeLMS and HerS. The colors of our candidate lensed DSFGs match those of the general HeLMS and HerS population. The error bars are standard deviations of the different populations.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj523326s4-2\" name=\"apj523326s4-2\">4.2.\u00a0Lensing Statistics</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The statistics of lensing at sub-millimeter wavelengths have been discussed extensively in Perrotta et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib76\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib76\">2002</a>), Negrello et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib70\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib70\">2007</a>), Lima et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib62\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib62\">2010</a>), Hezaveh &amp; Holder (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib49\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib49\">2011</a>), and Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) where similar techniques were used to identify lensed DSFGs in HerMES using <em>Herschel</em> 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m observations. The adopted model assumes a foreground mass profile and spatial distribution for the lensing galaxies, along with a redshift distribution of DSFGs with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 1</script></span></span> mJy, which was adopted from B\u00e9thermin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib7\">2012a</a>) for unlensed DSFGs. The model ultimately makes predictions regarding the properties of lensed DSFGs (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f5\">5</a> shows the cumulative 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m number counts of galaxies considering the assumptions above. The cumulative number counts of lensed candidates are reported in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t1\">1</a>. The confidence intervals in these measurements are calculated following the prescription of Gehrels (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib39\">1986</a>). We see a steep slope in the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m number counts of unlensed DSFGs, showing that the population of bright 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m sources should be dominated by gravitationally lensed objects along with bright local spirals in the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m data (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Cumulative 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m number counts as a function of the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux. The lensed galaxy candidate counts from HerS and HeLMS are overlaid in red. These are consistent with counts of lensed sources as predicted from lensing statistics (Wardlow et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) shown with the black line with the confidence interval in blue. For comparison, we show the unlensed source counts from the HerMES blank-field catalogs (Oliver et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib73\">2012</a>) and from P(D) analysis (Glenn et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib42\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib42\">2010</a>) as the gray shaded area and black squares, respectively. The total counts of <em>Herschel</em> detected sources in these fields will be presented in future studies (C.  Clarke et al. 2016, in preparation, S. J. Oliver et al. 2016, in preparation).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj523326t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nCumulative Number Density of Lensed Sources\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/suppdata/apj523326t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Flux Limit</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Number Density</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Low 68%<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326fn3\"><sup>a</sup></a>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">High 68%<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326fn3\"><sup>a</sup></a>\n</th>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">500 <em>\u03bc</em>m (mJy)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"${\\mathrm{deg}}^{-2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mathrm{deg}}^{-2}</script></span></span>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"${\\mathrm{deg}}^{-2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mathrm{deg}}^{-2}</script></span></span>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"${\\mathrm{deg}}^{-2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script
