align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.047</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">170</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.030</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.023</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.041</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">180</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.027</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.021</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.038</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">200</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.019</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.014</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.029</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">250</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.011</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.008</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.019</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">260</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.008</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.006</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.016</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">270</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.005</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.004</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.012</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">710</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.0027</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.0019</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.0088</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apj523326fn3\" id=\"apj523326fn3\"></a><sup> a</sup> Confidence intervals are calculated following the prescription of Gehrels (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib39\">1986</a>).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/suppdata/apj523326t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/823/1/17\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/suppdata/apj523326t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>According to the same lensing model, a 100 mJy flux cut produces a strong-lensing galaxy fraction of 32%\u201374% (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) with an intrinsic flux density distribution that peaks at 5 mJy for the DSFGs. Given the HeLMS and HerS detection limits, many of these sources would be undetected without the magnification boost coming from lensing. Another prediction of this statistical model is that source blending does not significantly affect the lensed DSFG selection. This takes into account the blending of several intrinsically faint sources within the <em>Herschel</em> beam size that could produce a source with a combined flux above 100 mJy at 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m. Based on simulations, Wardlow et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) estimated that the blending of fainter galaxies has a probability of less than <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"$5\\times {10}^{-5}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">5\\times {10}^{-5}</script></span></span> to account for a source with flux density greater than 100 mJy. Within our sample of 77 lensed candidates, we do not expect a single source to result from the blending of two random fainter galaxies and still be identified as a single source. This is a result of the rarity of the bright DSFGs.</p><p>This estimate, however, ignores physical associations, rare instances of DSFG-DSFG mergers, or especially SMG\u2013SMG mergers similar to those already uncovered with <em>Herschel</em> (e.g., Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>; Ivison et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib54\">2013</a>). Such sources are now believed to make up a considerable fraction of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy population. Among the 13 lensed candidates in HerMES (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>), 1 source was identified to be an SMG\u2013SMG merger at <em>z</em> = 2.3 using the Sub-Millimeter Array (SMA) and other follow-up observations (HXMM01 of Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib36\">2013</a>). Using ALMA in Cycle 0 (see Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib11\">2015</a>), an additional source from the group of 13 was found to be a blend of at least 3 DSFGs that are weakly to moderately lensed (with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"$1\\lt \\mu \\lt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\lt \\mu \\lt 2</script></span></span>) by a low-redshift galaxy that is 6 arcsec away from the centroid of the 3 ALMA-detected sources. While we do not have precise predictions, we expect 10%\u201315% of the sample to be SMG\u2013SMG mergers. Detailed follow-up studies of the statistically significant sample presented here, involving a total of 77 lensed candidates, can be used to estimate the fraction more precisely. The exact fraction of SMG\u2013SMG mergers, and their luminosity and mass distribution, are crucial for connecting such mergers with the formation history of the most massive and red galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj523326s4-3\" name=\"apj523326s4-3\">4.3.\u00a0Luminosities and Spectral Energy Distributions (SEDs)</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>For the subsample of lensed candidate DSFGs from HeLMS and HerS with CO-based redshifts, we deduce the observed total infrared luminosity (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{IR}}};$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{IR}}};</script></span></span> rest-frame 8\u20131000 <em>\u03bc</em>m) from the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE observations at 250, 350, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m using modified blackbody fit to the data as explained in Casey (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib16\">2012</a>). The modified blackbody takes into account variations in opacity and source emissivity. These fits are summarized in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f6\">6</a>. Two of the sources overlap with the observations of Su et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>), as discussed below, and we include their flux densities. For one of the targets, HERS1, we also include <em>Planck</em>-detected flux densities.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Far-infrared SED fits of the 13 HerS and HeLMS lens candidates with CO spectroscopic redshifts using a modified blackbody fit with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =1.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =1.5</script></span></span> (Casey <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib16\">2012</a>). The first two sources show millimeter-band observations from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (Su et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>) in filled red circles. HERS1 also has observations in millimeter-bands from Geach et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib38\">2015</a>; open circles) and data from the <em>Planck</em> point-source catalog which is represented as open green triangles. The total infrared luminosity (integrated over 8\u20131000 <em>\u03bc</em>m in units of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{Log}({L}_{\\odot })$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{Log}({L}_{\\odot })</script></span></span>) and far-infrared measured dust temperatures from the blackbody fits (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}</script></span></span>) are also reported for each object.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f7\">7</a> shows <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {L}_{{\\rm{IR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {L}_{{\\rm{IR}}}</script></span></span> as a function of spectroscopic redshift measured from CO observations. The DSFGs have measured total infrared luminosities between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"$1.1\\times {10}^{13}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.1\\times {10}^{13}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"$1.6\\times {10}^{14}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.6\\times {10}^{14}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> and a median of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"$4.9\\times {10}^{13}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4.9\\times {10}^{13}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>. Using a Kennicutt (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib57\">1998</a>) relation for star formation (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{SFR}\\ ({M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1})=4.5\\quad \\times \\quad {10}^{-44}\\;{L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}(\\mathrm{erg}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{SFR}\\ ({M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1})=4.5\\quad \\times \\quad {10}^{-44}\\;{L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}(\\mathrm{erg}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1})</script></span></span> with a Salpeter initial mass function; Salpeter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib87\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib87\">1955</a>), we infer a median star formation rate of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 8500\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 8500\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}</script></span></span>. In the above, <em>\u03bc</em> is the gravitational lensing magnification for the <em>Herschel</em>-selected lensed DSFGs. We can estimate the average maximum magnification as a function of the 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux from statistical gravitational lens modeling (Lapi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib60\">2012</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) and direct observations of large SMA-detected samples of lensed DSFGs and SMGs (Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>). The measured infrared luminosities for these targets far exceed those of normal star-forming and IR luminous systems, providing further evidence of gravitational lensing, which is consistent with previous studies of lensed DSFGs (Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>). In fact, given the average magnification for bright gravitationally lensed sources (Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>), we infer a total infrared luminosity of lensed DSFGs which is consistent with that of normal IR-bright galaxies at similar redshifts.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0Total observed infrared luminosity (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}</script></span></span>; rest-frame 8\u20131000 <em>\u03bc</em>m) measured from the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE data as a function of redshift. The DSFG redshifts are from spectroscopic CO observations by CARMA (D. A. Reichers et al. 2016, in preparation) and the GBT (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation). The curved dashed line shows the detection limit for our candidate lensed DSFGs from a modified blackbody model with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =1.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =1.5</script></span></span>, <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn71.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}=35\\;{\\rm{K}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}=35\\;{\\rm{K}}</script></span></span>, and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux of 100 mJy similar to our selection flux cut (see Casey <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib16\">2012</a>). For comparison, we show SPIRE-selected and millimeter-selected samples of star-forming galaxies from Casey et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib18\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib18\">2012</a>) and Roseboom et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib83\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib83\">2012</a>), respectively. Candidate lensed DSFGs identified by Wardlow et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) are shown with filled red circles. At any given redshift, the lensed DSFGs would have a total infrared luminosity that exceeds those of red star-forming galaxies because of the lensing magnification.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f8\">8</a> shows the dust temperature, derived from the SED fits as described above, as a function of the total infrared luminosity for our lensed DSFG candidates with spectroscopic redshifts in the HeLMS and HerS fields. The candidate lensed systems have observed dust temperatures ~25\u201340 K and total observed luminosities (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn72.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {L}_{{\\rm{IR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {L}_{{\\rm{IR}}}</script></span></span>) as reported above. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f8\">8</a> also shows the dust temperature and infrared luminosities of other samples of lensed DSFGs and SMGs from the literature (Magnelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib67\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>; Wei\u00df et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib113\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib113\">2013</a>; Canameras et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib13\">2015</a>) where we have converted the intrinsic values to observed properties given the derived magnifications in those studies. The spread in the distribution of these sources on the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn73.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn74.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}</script></span></span> plane is mostly associated with the different selection functions and also the intrinsic properties of each population. Our candidate DSFGs show a smaller scatter in the measured properties that is mainly associated with the use of the redshift information (from the CO observations) for these systems in our SED fits (Magnelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib67\">2012</a>). Our DSFG candidates have median SED measured dust temperatures of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn75.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}\\sim 31$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}\\sim 31</script></span></span> K. This indicates that our candidate DSFGs are more dominated by systems with cooler dust temperatures, which is more consistent with secular modes of star formation rather than merger-driven star formation activity (Magnelli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib67\">2012</a>), as is also evident from our high-resolution follow-up observations.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Dust temperature vs. total infrared luminosity for the candidate gravitationally lensed DSFGs in HeLMS and HerS. The temperature and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn76.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {L}_{\\mathrm{IR}}</script></span></span> (rest-frame 8\u20131000 <em>\u03bc</em>m) are plotted for a subsample of the lens candidates for which we have spectroscopic redshifts from CO observations by fitting a modified blackbody spectrum (see Casey <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib16\">2012</a>). The dust temperatures and infrared luminosities of several studies of lensed DSFGs and SMGs are shown for comparison (Magnelli et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib67\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>; Wei\u00df et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib113\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib113\">2013</a>; Canameras et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib13\">2015</a>). The smaller scatter in the derived dust temperatures is associated with the use of spectroscopic redshift information, from CO observations, in the SED fits. The lensed DSFGs have median dust temperatures of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn77.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}\\sim 31\\;{\\rm{K}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}\\sim 31\\;{\\rm{K}}</script></span></span> indicating a secular mode of star formation.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj523326s4-4\" name=\"apj523326s4-4\">4.4.\u00a0Example Lensed Sources</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>HERS1, shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f2\">2</a>, was already identified as a lensed galaxy by a citizen science group, <span class=\"small-caps\">SpaceWarps,</span> making use of VISTA-CFHT optical imaging data in SDSS Stripe 82 (Geach et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib38\">2015</a>). This is the brightest target in our list of 77 with a 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m flux density of 717 mJy. It is a unique source in that it stands out at the bright-end separately on its own while the next set of lensed candidate sources have flux densities well below 300 mJy. The Keck/NIRC2 LGSAO HELMS Deep K<sub><em>s</em></sub>band that we present in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f2\">2</a>, obtained prior to us knowing about the <span class=\"small-caps\">SpaceWarps</span> project and the Geach et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib38\">2015</a>) publication, has substantially better resolution than the VISTA-CFHT <em>K</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>-band image in Geach et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib38\">2015</a>). Unlike our previous lens follow-up programs in the <em>K</em> band which resulted in the need for deep integrations due to the faintness of the lensed source, HERS1 is bright enough in the <em>K</em> band that the lensing galaxy is easily visible in a single NIRC2 frame of 60 s.</p><p>Additional multi-wavelength observations of this target, including CO spectroscopy, are reported in Geach et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib38\">2015</a>). HERS1 is also detected in the <em>Planck</em> all-sky point-source catalog and is identified as PCCS2 857 G160.58-56.76 in the <em>Planck</em> 857 GHz point-source catalog with a separation of less than 1 arcminute from the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m position, which is smaller than the FWHM resolution of <em>Planck</em> (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 4^{\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 4^{\\prime}</script></span></span>) at 857 GHz. <em>Planck</em> has a 857 GHz flux of 1118 \u00b1 408 mJy and a 545 GHz flux of 676 \u00b1 197 mJy. These flux densities are consistent with the SPIRE 350 <em>\u03bc</em>m and 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m fluxes of 912 \u00b1 7 mJy and 718 \u00b1 8 mJy, respectively. The SED is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f6\">6</a>. Fixing <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =1.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =1.5</script></span></span> does not provide a good fit for HERS1 given the additional data that we have, particularly at longer wavelengths. We kept <em>\u03b2</em> as a free parameter (Casey <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib16\">2012</a>) while fitting the full SED of HERS1 with <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE, <em>Planck</em>, and ACT data, giving <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn80.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =1.9$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =1.9</script></span></span> and providing a better fit.</p><p>In a recent study, Su et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>) identified a sample of nine gravitationally lensed DSFGs using the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) in Stripe 82. Six of the nine lensing galaxies have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn81.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy. We had independently selected these six candidates in our sample, prior to our knowledge of the Su et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>) study or preprint, in the current sample of HerS/HeLMS candidate gravitationally lensed galaxies. The three targets not selected in our study have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn82.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\lt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\lt 100</script></span></span> mJy and fall outside of our lensed DSFG candidate selection. The far-infrared fluxes of all 12 ACT candidates are consistent with the <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE fluxes of the corresponding sources in our catalog, given the errors and the leeway in the SED fits. Two of the ACT-detected lensed galaxies in our catalog (HERS1 and HELMS29) have spectroscopic redshifts from CO observations (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation, D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation). HELMS29, at <em>z</em> = 5.162 (see below), is the highest-redshift lensing galaxy in our sample. We use this redshift along with the <em>Herschel</em> far-infrared and ACT millimeter data to construct the SED (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f6\">6</a>). Similar to HERS1, discussed above, we treated <em>\u03b2</em> as a free parameter in the SED fit of HELMS29. The addition of ACT data provided a better fit to the flux densities at longer wavelengths with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn83.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =2.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =2.6</script></span></span> (for more details on the fitting procedure, see Casey <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib16\">2012</a>). Su et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>) also present deep follow-up observations of their lensing sample, including the CO redshift of one additional source (their other redshift is for HERS1). Unfortunately, that source does not fall within the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn84.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy limit we have used in the present catalog. These independent follow-up campaigns by different groups (which we label as \"battle of HELMS deep\") will likely result in additional redshifts for the lens galaxy sample we have presented here.</p><p>Asboth et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>) discuss the \"red\" galaxies in HeLMS with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn85.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt {S}_{350}\\gt {S}_{250}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt {S}_{350}\\gt {S}_{250}</script></span></span>. Such a selection identifies candidate SMGs with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn86.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 4</script></span></span>, which is similar to the selection that led to HFLS3 (Riechers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib81\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib81\">2013</a>; Cooray et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib22\">2014</a>), as discussed in Dowell et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib27\">2014</a>). Six targets overlap between the two samples and are identified here in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t2\">2</a>. These sources are likely to be lensed galaxies with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn87.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 4</script></span></span>. One such candidate, HELMS29, has a CO-based redshift of 5.162 and is discussed in detail in Asboth et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). The redshift is also confirmed by an ALMA Cycle 1 observation (PI: Conley), as discussed in Asboth et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). The HeLMS and HerS candidate list presented here is also part of a ALMA Cycle 2 snapshot program (PI: Eales). Ten of the targets from the HeLMS list have secured observations at 350 GHz and those targets are identified in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t2\">2</a>. Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t2\">2</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t4\">4</a> in the Appendix summarize our identified lensed candidates. The ALMA data, lensing models, and multi-wavelength analysis will be presented in future papers.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326s5\" name=\"apj523326s5\">5.\u00a0SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We used <em>Herschel</em>/SPIRE maps of the HeLMS and HerS surveys to produce a list of candidate gravitationally lensed DSFGs. Our main findings are as follow.</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We identified 77 candidate lensed DSFGs in the combined 372 deg<sup>2</sup> region covered by the <em>Herschel</em> HeLMS and HerS fields (0.21 \u00b1 0.03 deg<sup>\u22122</sup>).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Candidate DSFGs are bright in the SPIRE 500 <em>\u03bc</em>m observations (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn88.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{500}\\gt 100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{500}\\gt 100</script></span></span> mJy by selection). We further show that the colors of our candidate DSFGs are redder than the local spiral galaxies, which is indicative of a separate population at high-redshift.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">A few of our brighter lensed DSFGs with red SEDs in the HeLMS field were recently discovered in a parallel study (Asboth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>). ACT also confirmed the existence of a small subsample of our lensed DSFG candidates (Su et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib100\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib100\">2015</a>). This further demonstrates the robustness of our selection of high-redshift lensed galaxies.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">High-resolution near-infrared follow-up observations of a few of the candidates with Keck/NIRC2 AO and the William Herschel Telescope (WHT) reveal arcs and distorted images associated with gravitational lensing.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Spectroscopic redshifts measured from CO molecular line observations (A. I. Harris et al. 2016, in preparation; D. A. Riechers et al. 2016, in preparation) for 13 of the candidates put the population of lensed DSFGs at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn89.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span>, whereas the foreground lensing galaxies have a redshift distribution that peaks at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn90.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 1</script></span></span>. This further supports the scenario of a population of distant objects being gravitationally lensed by nearby foreground galaxies.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We fit the far-infrared SED of the candidate lensed DSFGs with a modified blackbody which gives us the best-fit total infrared luminosity (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn91.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{\\mathrm{IR}};$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{\\mathrm{IR}};</script></span></span> rest-frame 8\u20131000 <em>\u03bc</em>m) and dust temperature (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn92.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}</script></span></span>). For the SED fittings, we fix the redshift of the galaxy to spectroscopic redshifts from CO observations. Two of the candidate DSFGs (HERS1 and HELMS29) also have longer wavelength data from ACT observations with HERS1 also being detected in the <em>Planck</em> point-source catalog. We use these additional data in our SED analysis.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">7.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The lensed DSFGs have median total infrared luminosities of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn93.gif\" alt=\"$4.9\\times {10}^{13}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4.9\\times {10}^{13}\\;{\\mu }^{-1}{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>, where <em>\u03bc</em> is the gravitational lensing magnification factor. The observed infrared luminosity for lensed DSFGs far exceeds that of normal star-forming galaxies at similar redshifts. In fact, given the average magnification for bright, gravitationally lensed sources (Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib10\">2013</a>), we infer a total infrared luminosity of lensed DSFGs consistent with that of normal IR-bright galaxies at similar redshifts.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">8.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The candidate lensed galaxies have SED measured dust temperatures in the range of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn94.gif\" alt=\"$25\\;{\\rm{K}}\\lt {T}_{d}\\lt 38\\;{\\rm{K}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">25\\;{\\rm{K}}\\lt {T}_{d}\\lt 38\\;{\\rm{K}}</script></span></span> with a median of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn95.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{d}\\sim 31\\;{\\rm{K}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{d}\\sim 31\\;{\\rm{K}}</script></span></span> and a small scatter given the spectroscopic CO information. The relatively low dust temperature compared to the merger-driven dust temperatures in the IR luminous galaxies at similar redshifts supports the secular star formation evolution within these systems.</div></li></ul><p>\n</p><p>Given the high success rate of high-redshift DSFG observations selected similarly from other studies (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib71\">2010</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib112\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib112\">2013</a>) and from our own follow-up high-resolution observations, we can conclude that the present catalog is a robust list of bona fide gravitationally lensed galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn96.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span>. About 10%\u201315% of the sample are likely luminous SMG\u2013SMG mergers that are of interest for understanding the formation paths of massive galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326ieqn97.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>. The lensing nature, properties of the lensed galaxies, and identification of SMG\u2013SMG mergers for further studies will require carefully planned follow-up campaigns with a variety of facilities in the future.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We wish to thank the anonymous referee for thoroughly reading the manuscript and providing very useful suggestions. Financial support for this work was provided by NSF through AST-1313319 for H.N. and A.C. and NSF REU support in AST-1313319 for M.K. The UCI group also acknowledges NASA support for Herschel/SPIRE GTO and Open-Time Programs. R.J.I. acknowledges support from the European Research Council in the form of the Advanced Investigator Programme, 321302, COSMICISM. J.L.W. is supported by a European Union COFUND/Durham Junior Research Fellowship under EU grant agreement number 267209, and acknowledges additional support from STFC (ST/L00075X/1). Support for I.P.F., P.I.M.N. and R.M.S. came from the Spanish MINECO grants AYA2010-21697-C05-4, FIS2012-39162-C06-02, and ESP2013-47809-C3-3-R. S.O. acknowledges support from the Science and Technology Facilities Council (grant number ST/L000652/1). Some of the data presented herein were obtained at the W.M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W.M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. Data presented herein were obtained using the UCI Remote Observing Facility, made possible by a generous gift from John and Ruth Ann Evans. The <em>Herschel</em> spacecraft was designed, built, tested, and launched under a contract to ESA managed by the <em>Herschel</em>/<em>Planck</em> Project team by an industrial consortium under the overall responsibility of the prime contractor Thales Alenia Space (Cannes), and including Astrium (Friedrichshafen) responsible for the payload module and for system testing at spacecraft level, Thales Alenia Space (Turin) responsible for the service module, and Astrium (Toulouse) responsible for the telescope, within excess of a hundred subcontractors. HCSS/HSpot/HIPE is a joint development (are joint developments) by the <em>Herschel</em> Science Ground Segment Consortium, consisting of ESA, the NASA <em>Herschel</em> Science Center, and the HIFI, PACS, and SPIRE consortia. The IRAM Plateau de Bure Interferometer is supported by INSU/CNRS (France), MPG (Germany), and IGN (Spain). The National Radio Astronomy Observatory is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated by Associated Universities, Inc. Support for CARMA construction was derived from the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, the Kenneth T. and Eileen L. Norris Foundation, the James S. McDonnell Foundation, the Associates of the California Institute of Technology, the University of Chicago, the states of California, Illinois, and Maryland, and the National Science Foundation. Ongoing CARMA development and operations are supported by NSF grant ATI-0838178 to CARMA, and by the CARMA partner universities. The William Herschel telescope is operated on the island of La Palma by the Isaac Newton Group in the Spanish Observatorio del Roque de los Muchachos of the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias. Based in part on observations made with the Gran Telescopio Canarias (GTC), installed at the Spanish Observatorio del Roque de los Muchachos of the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, in the island of La Palma. The research leading to these results has received funding from the European Union Seventh Framework Programme FP7/2007-2013/ under grant agreement n\u00b0 607254. This publication reflects only the author's view and the European Union is not responsible for any use that may be made of the information contained therein.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj523326app1\" name=\"apj523326app1\">APPENDIX: CANDIDATE LENSED GALAXIES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t2\">2</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t4\">4</a> summarize our identified lensed candidates.<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj523326t3\"> </a>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f9\"> </a>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj523326f10\"> </a>\n</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f9a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0The postage stamp images of the candidate gravitationally lensed DSFGs in the HeLMS field in the <em>Herschel</em> far-infrared, SDSS optical, and <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>; Wright et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib116\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib116\">2010</a>) infrared bands. The <em>Herschel</em> cutouts are from our <span class=\"small-caps\">sanepic</span> maps (see Asboth et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib4\">2016</a>) with the coordinates derived from the higher-resolution 250 <em>\u03bc</em>m observations. The SDSS data are from deep co-adds by Jiang et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib55\">2014</a>) when available and single epoch observations from SDSS DR12 when deeper data is not available. The infrared data are in the <em>WISE</em> W1 (at 3.4 <em>\u03bc</em>m) and W2 (at 4.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m) bands using unWISE images (Lang <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj523326bib59\" id=\"fnref-apj523326bib59\">2014</a>). The image scales are shown for the first row. The lensed candidates are point-like bright targets in the <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE cutouts. The SDSS and <em>WISE</em> cutouts show the lensing foreground galaxies.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj523326f9f\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadFigure/figure/apj523326f9f\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj523326f9f\" href=\"/0004-637X/823/1/17/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj523326f9f\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj523326f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj523326f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f10a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/823/1/17/Full/apj523326f10a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block
